title: Router
one_liner: The router is the box that connects your home or office network to the internet and decides where traffic goes.
owner_why_it_matters: If your router is old or poorly configured, it's often the weakest link attackers target first.

title: Firewall
one_liner: A firewall is a traffic bouncer that decides which network connections are allowed in or out.
owner_why_it_matters: A properly configured firewall can block most casual attacks and mistakes before they reach your devices.

title: Modem
one_liner: The modem is the device that speaks the language of your internet provider and brings the connection into your building.
owner_why_it_matters: Knowing where the modem ends and your network begins helps you see what you control versus what your ISP controls.

title: Guest Wi-Fi
one_liner: Guest Wi-Fi is a separate wireless network for visitors that keeps them away from your business devices and data.
owner_why_it_matters: Segregating guests from your main network makes it much harder for a visitor's infected device to harm your business.

title: VLAN (Virtual LAN)
one_liner: A VLAN is a way to slice one physical network into multiple logical networks, each with its own rules and boundaries.
owner_why_it_matters: Using VLANs lets you isolate risky devices like cameras or guest Wi-Fi from sensitive systems like POS and accounting.

title: MFA (Multi-Factor Authentication)
one_liner: MFA adds an extra step to logins, like a code on your phone, so a stolen password by itself isn't enough.
owner_why_it_matters: Turning on MFA for email, banking, and key business apps is the single highest-value, low-effort security upgrade.

title: Password Manager
one_liner: A password manager is a secure vault that stores and fills your passwords so you don't reuse or write them on sticky notes.
owner_why_it_matters: Using a password manager dramatically reduces weak passwords and makes staff onboarding/offboarding much cleaner.

title: VPN (Virtual Private Network)
one_liner: A VPN creates an encrypted tunnel so remote staff can securely connect into your office network or cloud systems.
owner_why_it_matters: Without a proper VPN, staff often use risky workarounds from home or public Wi-Fi that expose your data.

title: Backup
one_liner: Backups are copies of your important data stored somewhere else so you can recover from mistakes, failures, or attacks.
owner_why_it_matters: A tested backup can turn a ransomware attack from a business-ending event into a bad day.

title: Ransomware
one_liner: Ransomware is malware that encrypts your files and demands payment to unlock them.
owner_why_it_matters: Good backups, patching, and email protection can turn ransomware from a catastrophe into a recoverable incident.

title: Internet Service Provider (ISP)
one_liner: An ISP is the company that sells you internet access and often provides the modem and basic support.
owner_why_it_matters: Knowing what your ISP is responsible for helps you decide when to call them versus fixing your own gear.

title: Network Ports
one_liner: Ports are numbered doors that network traffic uses to reach the right app or service.
owner_why_it_matters: Open ports invite traffic; closing unnecessary ones reduces attack paths into your business.

title: Zero Trust
one_liner: Zero Trust means no device or user is trusted by default; every access is verified each time.
owner_why_it_matters: Assuming nothing is safe by default limits how far an attacker can move if they get in.

title: Phishing
one_liner: Phishing is when attackers send fake emails or messages to trick you into giving up info or clicking malware.
owner_why_it_matters: Most breaches start with a phish, so training and filters prevent expensive scams.

title: Endpoint Protection
one_liner: Endpoint protection is security software on laptops and desktops that blocks malware and risky behavior.
owner_why_it_matters: It is a primary shield against ransomware and other malware landing on employee devices.

title: Disaster Recovery
one_liner: Disaster recovery is the plan to restore systems and data after a major outage or attack.
owner_why_it_matters: A clear recovery plan means downtime is measured in hours instead of days or weeks.

title: Network Switch
one_liner: A switch connects multiple wired devices so they can talk inside your network.
owner_why_it_matters: Reliable switching keeps printers, servers, and VoIP phones talking without drops.

title: Access Point
one_liner: An access point is the dedicated device that broadcasts your Wi-Fi network.
owner_why_it_matters: Good access points give stable coverage and let you separate guest and staff networks.

title: Wi-Fi SSID
one_liner: An SSID is the network name you see when connecting to Wi-Fi.
owner_why_it_matters: Clear SSIDs help staff choose the right network and avoid risky lookalike networks.

title: Mesh Wi-Fi
one_liner: Mesh Wi-Fi uses multiple access points that work together to cover a whole building.
owner_why_it_matters: Mesh reduces dead zones so staff and devices stay connected across the office or home.

title: Bandwidth
one_liner: Bandwidth is the amount of data your connection can move at once.
owner_why_it_matters: Too little bandwidth means slow cloud apps and choppy calls that frustrate customers and staff.

title: Quality of Service (QoS)
one_liner: QoS lets you prioritize important traffic like calls over less urgent traffic.
owner_why_it_matters: Prioritizing voice or payment traffic prevents choppy calls and failed transactions during busy times.

title: Network Address Translation (NAT)
one_liner: NAT lets many devices share one public internet address by rewriting traffic.
owner_why_it_matters: NAT hides internal devices from the internet, reducing exposure and saving IP costs.

title: DHCP
one_liner: DHCP automatically hands out IP addresses to devices on your network.
owner_why_it_matters: Automatic addressing prevents conflicts that knock devices offline.

title: DNS
one_liner: DNS translates easy names like example.com into the numeric addresses computers use.
owner_why_it_matters: When DNS breaks, websites and apps feel down even if your internet is up.

title: Local Area Network (LAN)
one_liner: A LAN is your internal network that connects devices in one location.
owner_why_it_matters: A healthy LAN keeps printers, storage, and apps reachable without lag.

title: Wide Area Network (WAN)
one_liner: A WAN links multiple sites or remote users over the internet or private circuits.
owner_why_it_matters: Your WAN quality drives how usable remote offices and cloud apps feel.

title: Ethernet
one_liner: Ethernet is the wired standard for connecting devices with network cables.
owner_why_it_matters: Wired connections are faster and more stable for servers, VoIP, and printers.

title: Port Forwarding
one_liner: Port forwarding tells your router to send specific incoming traffic to a device inside your network.
owner_why_it_matters: Misconfigured forwarding can expose devices to the internet; use it only when necessary.

title: Remote Access
one_liner: Remote access lets staff reach office resources from home or on the road.
owner_why_it_matters: Secure remote access keeps work moving without creating openings for attackers.

title: Dynamic DNS
one_liner: Dynamic DNS updates a domain name when your public IP address changes.
owner_why_it_matters: It keeps remote access working even when your ISP changes your IP.

title: IPv4
one_liner: IPv4 is the older, widely used internet addressing system with limited addresses.
owner_why_it_matters: Most gear still relies on IPv4, so you need to support it even as IPv6 grows.

title: IPv6
one_liner: IPv6 is the newer addressing system with a huge pool of internet addresses.
owner_why_it_matters: New services and ISPs are moving to IPv6, so your gear should handle it.

title: SSL/TLS
one_liner: SSL/TLS is the encryption that protects data in transit between browsers and services.
owner_why_it_matters: Without TLS, logins and payments can be stolen in transit.

title: HTTPS
one_liner: HTTPS is the secure, encrypted version of HTTP used by websites.
owner_why_it_matters: Using HTTPS protects customer data and avoids browser security warnings.

title: Digital Certificate
one_liner: A certificate is a digital ID that proves a website or service is who it claims to be.
owner_why_it_matters: Valid certificates prevent users from being tricked by fake login pages.

title: Split Tunneling
one_liner: Split tunneling lets some traffic go through a VPN while other traffic goes direct to the internet.
owner_why_it_matters: It can improve speed but must be managed so sensitive traffic still stays protected.

title: Network-Attached Storage (NAS)
one_liner: A NAS is a small file server for shared storage and backups on your network.
owner_why_it_matters: Central storage simplifies backups and access control for business files.

title: Server
one_liner: A server is a computer that provides shared services like files, apps, or databases.
owner_why_it_matters: Keeping servers patched and powered protects the apps your business relies on.

title: Desktop / Workstation
one_liner: A desktop or workstation is a fixed employee computer used for daily work.
owner_why_it_matters: Secure, updated desktops reduce support calls and malware risk.

title: Laptop
one_liner: A laptop is a portable computer staff use on the go.
owner_why_it_matters: Laptops are easy to lose; encryption and MFA keep lost devices from becoming data leaks.

title: Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS)
one_liner: A UPS is a battery that keeps equipment running through short power losses.
owner_why_it_matters: It prevents sudden shutdowns that corrupt servers, storage, and network gear.

title: Network Printer
one_liner: A network printer can be reached over Wi-Fi or Ethernet by multiple users.
owner_why_it_matters: Keeping printer firmware updated closes easy backdoors attackers target.

title: Security Camera
one_liner: A security camera records video for safety and monitoring.
owner_why_it_matters: Cameras should be isolated so a hacked camera can't reach business systems.

title: Smart TV
one_liner: A smart TV is an internet-connected display for streaming or signage.
owner_why_it_matters: Putting smart TVs on guest or IoT networks keeps them from mixing with business data.

title: IoT Hub
one_liner: An IoT hub connects and manages smart devices like sensors, locks, or lights.
owner_why_it_matters: Keeping IoT gear segmented prevents a hacked gadget from reaching business apps.

title: POS Terminal
one_liner: A POS terminal is the card reader or register that processes customer payments.
owner_why_it_matters: Segregating POS devices reduces the chance of card data theft and keeps you compliant.

title: VoIP Phone
one_liner: A VoIP phone makes calls over the internet instead of phone lines.
owner_why_it_matters: Proper QoS and power keep calls clear so you don't miss sales or support calls.

title: Remote Desktop
one_liner: Remote desktop lets you view and control a computer from afar.
owner_why_it_matters: Securing remote desktop with VPN and MFA prevents easy break-ins.

title: Spear Phishing
one_liner: Spear phishing is a targeted scam email crafted for a specific person or role.
owner_why_it_matters: Targeted scams often bypass generic filters, so training and MFA are key.

title: Business Email Compromise (BEC)
one_liner: BEC is when attackers hijack or spoof business email to redirect money or data.
owner_why_it_matters: A single fake invoice can quietly move thousands of dollars out of your account.

title: Spam Filtering
one_liner: Spam filtering blocks junk and malicious email before it reaches users.
owner_why_it_matters: Fewer bad emails means fewer chances for staff to click something dangerous.

title: Email Filtering
one_liner: Email filtering inspects messages for spam, malware, and impersonation.
owner_why_it_matters: Good filtering removes most threats before they reach employees' inboxes.

title: SPF
one_liner: SPF is a DNS record that lists which servers can send email for your domain.
owner_why_it_matters: SPF reduces spoofed mail that can trick staff or customers.

title: DKIM
one_liner: DKIM signs outgoing email so recipients can verify it wasn't altered.
owner_why_it_matters: Signed email builds trust and helps filters catch forgeries.

title: DMARC
one_liner: DMARC tells receivers how to handle email that fails SPF or DKIM checks.
owner_why_it_matters: Proper DMARC policy blocks spoofed mail that could trick staff or customers.

title: Malware
one_liner: Malware is malicious software designed to harm or steal from your systems.
owner_why_it_matters: Malware can steal data or halt operations, costing time and money.

title: Computer Virus
one_liner: A virus is malware that spreads by infecting files or programs.
owner_why_it_matters: Viruses can corrupt data and slow systems, hurting productivity.

title: Trojan
one_liner: A trojan is malware that pretends to be legitimate software to get installed.
owner_why_it_matters: Trojans often steal credentials or open backdoors for attackers.

title: Worm
one_liner: A worm is malware that spreads itself across networks without user action.
owner_why_it_matters: Worms can quickly knock out many systems at once if patching is weak.

title: Spyware
one_liner: Spyware secretly monitors activity or steals information from a device.
owner_why_it_matters: Spyware can capture customer data or logins without being noticed.

title: Social Engineering
one_liner: Social engineering is tricking people into giving access or information.
owner_why_it_matters: Even strong tech fails if staff can be convinced to bypass it.

title: Password
one_liner: A password is the secret phrase used to prove who you are when logging in.
owner_why_it_matters: Weak or reused passwords are an easy way in for attackers.

title: Passphrase
one_liner: A passphrase is a longer, easier-to-remember password made of several words.
owner_why_it_matters: Long passphrases are stronger and harder to guess or crack.

title: Password Policy
one_liner: A password policy sets rules for creating and managing passwords.
owner_why_it_matters: Clear rules reduce weak passwords and help with compliance.

title: Credential Stuffing
one_liner: Credential stuffing is using stolen passwords from one site to break into another.
owner_why_it_matters: Reused passwords let attackers hop from old breaches into your business accounts.

title: Patching
one_liner: Patching means installing updates that fix security bugs and stability issues.
owner_why_it_matters: Unpatched systems are easy targets for ransomware and worms.

title: Auto-Updates
one_liner: Auto-updates automatically install new software patches.
owner_why_it_matters: Automation keeps systems protected without waiting for manual work.

title: Vulnerability Scan
one_liner: A vulnerability scan checks systems for known security holes.
owner_why_it_matters: Finding issues before attackers do lets you patch on your schedule.

title: Penetration Test
one_liner: A penetration test simulates an attack to find weaknesses in your defenses.
owner_why_it_matters: Pen tests reveal gaps so you can fix them before criminals exploit them.

title: Encryption
one_liner: Encryption scrambles data so only authorized people can read it.
owner_why_it_matters: Encrypting data in transit and at rest protects customer and financial info.

title: Disk Encryption
one_liner: Disk encryption protects the contents of a device if it is lost or stolen.
owner_why_it_matters: A stolen laptop with encryption is much less likely to become a data breach.

title: Email Encryption
one_liner: Email encryption protects sensitive messages so only intended recipients can read them.
owner_why_it_matters: Encrypted email keeps invoices, contracts, and personal data private in transit.

title: Data Classification
one_liner: Data classification labels information by sensitivity, like public or confidential.
owner_why_it_matters: Knowing what is sensitive guides who can access it and how it is protected.

title: Least Privilege
one_liner: Least privilege means users get only the access they need and no more.
owner_why_it_matters: Limiting access shrinks the damage a stolen account can cause.

title: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
one_liner: RBAC assigns permissions based on job roles instead of individuals.
owner_why_it_matters: Roles keep access consistent and make onboarding and offboarding faster.

title: Admin Account
one_liner: An admin account can change settings, install software, and manage other accounts.
owner_why_it_matters: Using admin accounts only when needed reduces accidental or malicious damage.

title: Standard Account
one_liner: A standard account is an everyday user login with limited permissions.
owner_why_it_matters: Working in standard accounts lowers the blast radius of mistakes or malware.

title: Service Account
one_liner: A service account is used by applications or automations instead of people.
owner_why_it_matters: Tracking service accounts prevents forgotten logins that attackers can abuse.

title: Logging
one_liner: Logging records what systems and users are doing over time.
owner_why_it_matters: Logs let you spot issues quickly and investigate incidents.

title: Log Forwarding
one_liner: Log forwarding sends copies of logs to a central place for analysis.
owner_why_it_matters: Central logs make it easier to catch problems and meet compliance needs.

title: SIEM
one_liner: A SIEM collects and correlates logs to spot suspicious activity.
owner_why_it_matters: SIEM alerts you to attacks early so you can respond before damage grows.

title: Incident Response
one_liner: Incident response is the process for handling security events and outages.
owner_why_it_matters: A rehearsed response limits downtime and costs when something goes wrong.

title: Security Awareness Training
one_liner: Security awareness training teaches staff how to spot and avoid common threats.
owner_why_it_matters: Educated staff are less likely to click scams that lead to costly incidents.

title: USB Security
one_liner: USB security covers safe use of flash drives and external devices.
owner_why_it_matters: Infected USB drives can spread malware or steal data instantly.

title: Physical Security
one_liner: Physical security protects buildings, rooms, and hardware from unauthorized access.
owner_why_it_matters: Locking down spaces prevents theft or tampering with your equipment.

title: Wi-Fi Security
one_liner: Wi-Fi security covers encryption, passwords, and settings that protect wireless networks.
owner_why_it_matters: Secure Wi-Fi keeps neighbors or attackers from snooping on your traffic.

title: WPA3
one_liner: WPA3 is the latest Wi-Fi security standard that improves encryption and login strength.
owner_why_it_matters: Using WPA3 makes it harder for attackers to crack your Wi-Fi password.

title: Static IP
one_liner: A static IP is an address that does not change over time.
owner_why_it_matters: Static IPs make remote access and services more reliable.

title: Remote Work Policy
one_liner: A remote work policy sets expectations and requirements for working offsite.
owner_why_it_matters: Clear rules reduce risk when staff connect from home networks.

title: BYOD Policy
one_liner: A BYOD policy defines how personal devices can be used for work.
owner_why_it_matters: Rules for personal devices prevent data leaks and support headaches.

title: Mobile Device Management (MDM)
one_liner: MDM is software that enforces security settings on phones and tablets.
owner_why_it_matters: MDM lets you wipe lost phones and ensure work data stays protected.

title: Remote Wipe
one_liner: Remote wipe lets you erase a device's data if it is lost or stolen.
owner_why_it_matters: Being able to wipe devices quickly prevents data from falling into the wrong hands.

title: Stolen Device
one_liner: A stolen device incident is when a laptop or phone goes missing and may expose data.
owner_why_it_matters: Planning for lost devices reduces legal and reputational fallout.

title: Asset Inventory
one_liner: Asset inventory is the list of all hardware and software you own or manage.
owner_why_it_matters: You can't protect or update what you don't know you have.

title: Device Onboarding
one_liner: Device onboarding is the process of setting up new equipment with the right settings and security.
owner_why_it_matters: Consistent onboarding prevents misconfigurations that lead to downtime or breaches.

title: Device Offboarding
one_liner: Device offboarding is retiring or repurposing equipment safely.
owner_why_it_matters: Proper offboarding ensures data is wiped and access is removed before devices leave.

title: Acceptable Use Policy
one_liner: An acceptable use policy explains how staff may use company devices and networks.
owner_why_it_matters: Clear guidance reduces risky behavior and supports disciplinary action when needed.

title: Business Continuity Plan
one_liner: A business continuity plan outlines how the business keeps operating during disruptions.
owner_why_it_matters: Planning ahead keeps revenue and customer service running during outages.

title: Change Management
one_liner: Change management is the process for planning and approving IT changes.
owner_why_it_matters: Structured changes reduce outages from rushed or untested updates.

title: Documentation
one_liner: Documentation records how systems are set up and how to operate them.
owner_why_it_matters: Good docs speed up troubleshooting and onboarding new staff or vendors.

title: Runbook
one_liner: A runbook is a step-by-step guide for handling routine tasks or incidents.
owner_why_it_matters: Runbooks make responses repeatable so fixes are fast and consistent.

title: Data Retention
one_liner: Data retention sets how long you keep different kinds of data.
owner_why_it_matters: Keeping data only as long as needed reduces legal risk and storage cost.

title: Vendor Management
one_liner: Vendor management tracks third-party providers, their access, and their performance.
owner_why_it_matters: Managing vendors reduces surprises from outages or security gaps in outside services.

title: Service Level Agreement (SLA)
one_liner: An SLA is a contract that defines service expectations like uptime and response times.
owner_why_it_matters: Clear SLAs set accountability with ISPs and vendors when things break.

title: Uptime Monitoring
one_liner: Uptime monitoring checks whether your websites or services are reachable.
owner_why_it_matters: Early alerts let you fix outages before customers notice.

title: Monitoring Alerts
one_liner: Monitoring alerts notify you when systems are down or behaving abnormally.
owner_why_it_matters: Fast alerts reduce downtime and lost revenue.

title: Remote Monitoring and Management (RMM)
one_liner: RMM tools let you monitor, patch, and support devices remotely.
owner_why_it_matters: Remote management keeps devices healthy without onsite visits.

title: Automation Platform
one_liner: An automation platform connects apps and triggers workflows without manual steps.
owner_why_it_matters: Automations save time and reduce mistakes in repetitive tasks.

title: Webhook
one_liner: A webhook is a push notification from one service to another when something happens.
owner_why_it_matters: Webhooks let systems talk to each other instantly without polling or manual exports.

title: API Key Management
one_liner: API key management controls and rotates the secret tokens apps use to talk to each other.
owner_why_it_matters: Protecting keys prevents outsiders from abusing your integrations or data.

title: Secrets Management
one_liner: Secrets management stores passwords, keys, and certificates securely for apps and admins.
owner_why_it_matters: Centralized secrets reduce hardcoded passwords and accidental leaks.

title: Secrets Vault
one_liner: A secrets vault is the protected storage location for credentials and keys.
owner_why_it_matters: A vault limits who can see sensitive credentials and keeps an audit trail.

title: Scheduled Tasks
one_liner: Scheduled tasks run jobs automatically at set times.
owner_why_it_matters: Automating routine jobs like backups reduces human error and saves time.

title: Privacy Policy
one_liner: A privacy policy explains what data you collect and how you use and protect it.
owner_why_it_matters: Clear privacy practices build trust and reduce legal exposure.

title: Compliance Audit
one_liner: A compliance audit checks whether your practices meet required standards or laws.
owner_why_it_matters: Regular audits catch gaps before regulators or customers do.

title: Data Loss Prevention (DLP)
one_liner: DLP tools detect and block sensitive data from leaving through email, web, or devices.
owner_why_it_matters: DLP helps stop accidental leaks of customer or financial information.

title: Cloud Backup
one_liner: Cloud backup stores copies of your data in a secure offsite service.
owner_why_it_matters: Offsite backups protect you if local devices are stolen, flooded, or encrypted by ransomware.

title: DNS Filtering
one_liner: DNS filtering blocks devices from reaching known malicious or risky domains.
owner_why_it_matters: Filtering stops many malware and phishing sites before a page even loads.

title: Browser Updates
one_liner: Browser updates patch security flaws and improve compatibility for web apps.
owner_why_it_matters: Outdated browsers are easy targets for drive-by attacks and web glitches.

title: RAID
one_liner: RAID combines multiple disks for redundancy or speed in servers and NAS devices.
owner_why_it_matters: RAID keeps storage available if one disk fails, buying time to replace it.

title: Network Video Recorder (NVR)
one_liner: An NVR stores video from IP security cameras on your network.
owner_why_it_matters: Isolating NVRs and backing them up protects evidence and privacy.

title: PCI DSS
one_liner: PCI DSS is the security standard for handling payment card data.
owner_why_it_matters: Following PCI reduces fines and protects customer card information.

title: Power over Ethernet (PoE)
one_liner: PoE sends power and data over one Ethernet cable to devices like phones or cameras.
owner_why_it_matters: PoE simplifies installs and keeps phones or cameras up during power issues when paired with a UPS.

title: Access Control System
one_liner: An access control system manages badges, keypads, or apps to unlock doors.
owner_why_it_matters: Controlling physical access protects equipment and sensitive spaces.

title: Smart Lock
one_liner: A smart lock is a networked door lock that can be controlled or monitored remotely.
owner_why_it_matters: Smart locks let you grant or revoke access quickly without rekeying.

title: Visitor Management
one_liner: Visitor management tracks who enters your space and where they can go.
owner_why_it_matters: Logging visitors improves safety and helps investigations if something goes missing.

title: IP Addressing
one_liner: IP addressing is the numbering system that lets devices find each other on networks.
owner_why_it_matters: Understanding addressing helps you troubleshoot why devices can't reach each other.
